Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content:
Can someone respond to this criticism of Komodo:

"Komodo has 64 trusted "notary nodes", and they get elected every year.
Elections are not cryptoeconomically secure. 

Once you abandon cryptoeconomically security, it is easy to process transactions super fast.
But you have a product that isn't interesting.
If someone can steal your money, it doesn't matter how fast it is."

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Technically the scaleing solution requires trust in yuor notary nodes....

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Because they are the ones who decide which chains are fungible

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: for everything else... Notary is a normal node... no speical powers

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Has to be said it is a collective trust also.... all notaries must agree on which chains are fungible. May be possible for enough of them to make up the minimum sigs to notarise a chain enough times to get a migrate through. Seems hard to pull off though.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content:
I skimmed this, but I'm trying to digest it: https://blog.komodoplatform.com/delayed-proof-of-work-explained-9a74250dbb86

It also doesn't talk about the scaling solution, like you said, @blackjok3r. I would like a summary of the worst case scenario.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
what do you mean worst case senario ? 
The scaling solution has fungible chains, so if every notary node conspired to create a new chain, with a huge premine than notarise it in the cluster, then they can inflate supply. This is unlikely to happen. But it could eb done none the less.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: For #kmdlabs  we are trying to think of many ways to stop this even being possible... you need to game theory it out, so that the notaries dopnt have enconmic incentive to band together to do this...

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: To me... if they are already earnming enough coins, it would be suicide to inflate the supply, because you decrease the value of existing coins.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: It's feasible that a state actor can corrupt all notaries using power / force. What if notaries were anonymous, their locations anonymous, and they are chosen randomly after meeting a minimum criteria requirement?

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: If that's possible, it might be as cryptoeconomically secure as BTC imo.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: The other solution to scalability in my opinion is designing a system that requires a deposit that is worth equal to the total amount of damage that can be cause by an attack. If we can see an attack for what it is, we don't have to worry about money being stolen. The worst that can happen is a hard fork. But hard forking will obviously disrupt financial transactions for a certain amount of time, until people are migrated to the truthful chain. How much damage can this cause? We don't know. It's up to every person transacting at the moment. The higher the deposit required, the higher the fee will be, obviously. So it's a lot like insurance, but this insurance will be cheaper, because the insurer has control over whether the insured event occurs.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: One idea we had to launch chains int he cluster was to burn the supply and add the chain params to OP_RETURN.... Then you can use the crosschain to check the tx has happend and was notarisaed before launching the chain... For now this will be a manual process but if ut can be coded.... then notaries themselvs cant even cheat.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: The real question is, what tech will make blockchain go mainstream? Komodo is a competitor to Ethereum if Ethereum thinks it doesn't need Komodo, even though they aren't the same thing. For example, if your co-worker thinks they can take over your job at a cheaper cost to your employer, they are a competitor, even if you do two different jobs. Does that make sense? It's all about whether Komodo is needed for mainstream crypto adoption or not.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: Also the important thing is: the only bad thing notaries can do is withhold notarizations. And for a notarized chain its best practice to not consider a transaction final until it is notarized. So if the notarizations are not coming in, there is   a problem and you shouldn't accept transactions. So there are no double spends
